Designing of low cost catalytic system for new CC/CN/CO bond formation reactions is very challenging in synthetic organic chemistry. Herein, we report a new Ag NPs immobilized porous organic polymer (POP) material Ag-NPs@PDVTA-1 by grafting of Ag nanoparticles at the surface of a POP material PDVTA-1. PDVTA-1 has been synthesized via radical co-polymerization of divinylbenzene and triallylamine under solvothermal reaction conditions. PDVTA-1 as well as the Ag-loaded catalyst Ag-NPs@PDVTA-1 are fully characterized to understand their physico-chemical properties. Ag-NPs@PDVTA-1 is used as heterogeneous nanocatalyst for the one pot three component A3 coupling reaction of aldehyde, secondary amine and terminal alkyne for the synthesis of a wide range of propargylamine derivatives under mild and eco-friendly reaction conditions. The desired products were obtained in high yields over this environmentally safe catalyst under optimized reaction conditions. Remarkably high specific surface area of Ag-NPs@PDVTA-1 (694 m2g−1) and its highly accessible catalytically active Ag-sites in the nano-architecture potentially makes it an efficient catalyst as reflected from the respective turn over numbers. The catalyst was collected and reused for several reaction cycles without any noticeable decline in its catalytic activity, suggesting its high merit in heterogeneous catalysis for the synthesis of value added CC/CN coupling products via one pot coupling reaction. Graphical abstract Ag nanoparticles grafted porous organic polymer as an efficient heterogeneous catalyst for solvent-free A3 coupling reactions Bijan Krishna Chandra, Satyajit Pal, Adinath Majee*, Asim Bhaumik* We have grafted Ag NPs at the surface of a porous organic polymer and resulting Ag-Naocatalyst showed excellent catalytic activity for the synthesis of propargylamines via A3 coupling reaction under solvent free conditions. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Porous-organic polymer Grafting of Ag NPs One pot three component A3 coupling Heterogeneous catalysis Recyclability Data availability The authors do not have permission to share data. 1. Introduction Porous organic polymers (POPs) [1,2], with high surface area and accessible micropores/mesopores can be synthesized via wide range of chemical reactions between the reactive functional moieties of the precursor organic monomers and this has attracted enormous interest over the past decades. Due to their huge application potentials, designing of these customised POPs at the molecular level using cheap and simple processes is highly desirable. POPs are often employed in gas storage/ separation, sensing, metal ion adsorption, photocatalysis and heterogeneous catalysis and so on [3–8]. Overwhelming features like high surface area, high physicochemical and hydrothermal stability together with nanoscale porosity have motivated us to employ them for designing suitable heterogeneous catalysts [9,10]. A wide diversity of organic porous materials has been reported till date viz. conjugated microporous polymers (CMPs), covalent triazine frameworks (CTFs) polymers with intrinsic micro porosity [PIMs] and covalent organic frameworks (COFs) are prepared via extended polymerization reactions between the multipodal organic monomers and successfully applied for efficient and robust heterogeneous catalysts [11–13]. Among these materials POPs are gaining huge interest as their surface can be grafted with different transition and non-transition metal/metal oxide nanoparticles, which can catalyze a wide range of liquid phase chemical transformations [14,15]. Since, POPs are often bearing electron donor N atoms such as 1°/2°/3° amine, imidazole, pyridine, etc. as in-built moieties, the lone electron pair of N atom can interact with the metal nanoparticles to provide the stability of the supported materials [16,17]. Further, high surface area and larger pore volume of the POPs could facilitate the easy diffusion of organic reactants through the pores of the material with suitable dipolar interaction and thus provide necessary exposure of the active sites in these catalysts [18,19]. During the past decades, multi-component reactions (MCRs) had been extensively used in target-oriented synthesis (TOS) to design and prepare compounds, having diverse functionalities with broad spectrum of applications [20–22]. Literature survey reveals that these ideal reactions involve the amicable chemistry that can run via one-pot procedure and these are very demanding in synthetic organic chemistry. The A3 coupling reaction is one of the most popular MCR utilized for the synthesis of propargylamines, which provides water as the only by-product [23,24]. Due to strict environmental regulations environmentally benign, efficient, economical and in target oriented green synthesis perfect combination of efficient catalyst and one pot MCRs are necessary like lock-n-key combination. Series of reports are there facilitating A3 coupling reaction, such as by employing organic media, water, ionic liquid, or under neat conditions catalyzed by copper, silver, gold, iron, nickel, cobalt, mercury or iridium based catalysts via catalytic CH activation [25–28]. The resultant propargylamine derivatives are familiar as multipurpose building blocks for the synthesis of many nitrogen containing heterocycles, agrochemicals, natural and pharmaceutical products [29,30]. Alzheimer's and Parkinson's diseases are treated by some of these medicinally demanding compounds that can be synthesized via A3 coupling reactions [31]. All these conventional systems often require the use of toxic reagents, hazardous organic solvents as well as harmful metal and expensive ligand sources in the presence of homogeneous strong acid and base catalysts. Cost effectiveness of the biologically active compounds and large scale industrial synthesis are often major concerns. Again, in homogeneous catalysis the separation/ purification and recovery of the metal catalysts is very difficult, or practically impossible. Further, major drawbacks of these classical methods are: (i) requirement of harsh reaction conditions, which might be harmful for the sensitive functional groups, (ii) difficult to stop the reactions at the amide stage and (iii) to stop further hydrolysis to the carboxylic acid often takes place, especially in basic media [32,33]. However, previous literature validated that the coinage metals are the most intriguing to catalyze A3 coupling reaction, where they can boost the production of the target molecule through coordinating to the terminal alkyne and creating π complexes. Among these, silver have proven to be the most effective for providing access to the desired compounds in good yields and high selectivities [29,30,34–38]. It is pertinent to mention that nanoparticles (NPs) are more reactive compared to their bulk counterparts because smaller size NPs possesses high surface to volume ratio and consequently provides large number of potential active sites. But metallic NPs are not stable (reduced thermodynamic stabilities) as they are associated with high surface energy. Thus modifications such as the addition of ligands and capping agents or the formation of core shell type particles or immobilization of metallic NPs into an appropriate solid support has to be done to boost the stability of the material [39]. Unfortunately, these modification processes often results in facile aggregation of NPs and may form deactivated bulk mass, which in turn leads to poor activities and reusability. Thus to mitigate, a combination of supports and NPs is a promising way of designing the catalyst. Indeed, the ease of separation, the simple regeneration, and the high stabilities of supported catalysts have spurred the latest development of heterogeneous nanocatalysis [40]. In this context, we have synthesised a porous organic polymer PDVTA-1 with high surface area and bearing tertiary amine fraction via non-aqueous polymerization of the monomers divinylbenzene and triallylamine under solvothermal conditions using AIBN as a radical initiator and further decorated its surface with finely dispersed Ag NPs to yield an efficient heterogeneous catalyst Ag-NPs@PDVTA-1(Scheme 1 ). Both the pristine POP PDVTA-1 and Ag-NPs@PDVTA-1 are thoroughly characterized and the catalytic activity of the supported Ag NPs are explored in this one pot A3 coupling reaction for the synthesis of value added propargylamine derivatives. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Chemicals used The chemicals used in this work are mentioned below with their corresponding manufacturers. a) Divinylbenzene (Sigma-Aldrich, India). b) Triallylamine (Sigma-Aldrich, India). c) AIBN (SRL, India). d) Hydrazine hydride (Spectrochem, India). e) Silver nitrate (Merck, India). f) All Commercially available substrates were used for the catalytic study (Aldrich, Merck and Spectrochem, India). g) All other solvents used were of analytical grade (Merck, India). TLC was done on a silica gel-coated glass slide (Merck, Silica gel G for TLC). Silica gel (60–120 mesh, SRL, India) was used for column chromatography. Here all chemicals were used without further purification and all solvents were distilled prior to use, glass apparatus were properly cleaned and oven dried before use and deionised water is used in all purposes. 2.2 Synthesis of PDVTA-1 porous polymer PDVTA-1 porous polymer was synthesized via non-aqueous polymerization of its monomer divinylbenzene and triallylamine under solvothermal condition using AIBN as a radical initiator [4,41]. In this typical synthesis, 781 mg divinylbenzene (6 mmol) and 206 mg triallylamine (1.5 mmol) were added in 15 mL acetone as taken in an oven dried round bottom flask and the mixture was stirred for 15 min. The flask was purged with nitrogen gas and 25 mg AIBN (0.15 mmol) was added to the mixture and the resulting slurry was stirred for 4 h under nitrogen atmosphere at room temperature. Then the resultant slurry was autoclaved at 120 °C to proceed to 24 h for static solvothermal reaction. The final milky white product was washed thoroughly with acetone and dried under air. Then the guest free porous material was obtained by Soxhlet extraction with 50:50 acetone-methanols for 48 h and dried overnight under air. The isolated yield of the hydrophobic milky white PDVTA-1 POP material was obtained 83 wt%. 2.3 Synthesis of Ag-NPs@PDVTA-1 catalyst It is known to us that the amount of metal source and reduction time controls particle sizes/aggregation of nanoparticles [36]. Keeping this in mind, in this typical synthesis 200 mg PDVTA-1 POP was dispersed overnight in 25 mL water mixed with 10 mL EtOH in a glass beaker. 20 mg AgNO3 was dissolved in 5 mL water at a glass vial by sonication. The prepared AgNO3 solution was added by micropipette very slowly into the dispersed POP at room temperature with 1 h mechanical stirring. 0.5 mL hydragine hydride added very slowly using micropipette at RT. Instantaneous color change was noticed; and the final slurry was stirred for 24 h. The material was washed thoroughly with water and ethanol to remove residuals and the final catalyst was filtered off and oven dried at 100 °C (Scheme 1) [42]. Then the material was characterized thoroughly and after getting satisfactory characterization results, its catalytic activity was explored. Assuming the loading of one Ag atom per nitrogen site in the proposed model of PDVTA-1 (Scheme 1) the theoretical loading of Ag over this porous polymer was 11.52 wt%. Thus, we have prepared three Ag-NPs@PDVTA-1 samples with the impregnation of 10, 15 and 20 wt% AgNO3 on PDVTA-1. 2.4 General procedure for A3 coupling reaction catalyzed by Ag-NPs@PDVTA-1 In a typical experiment, a three-component mixture of 4-methylbenzaldehyde (1 mmol), morpholine (1.2 mmol) and phenylacetylene (1.5 mmol) was stirred in presence of 5 mg Ag-NPs@PDVTA-1 at 100 °C in solvent-free neat condition for 12 h in open air. The progress of the reaction was monitored by TLC, and the mixture was cooled at room temperature and then diluted with saturated saline water (3 × 15 mL), and extracted with ethyl acetate. The combined organic layers were collected and dried with anhydrous Na2SO4. The residue was purified by column chromatography on silica gel (eluent: ethyl acetate/petroleum ether) to afford the desired propargylamine [4-(3-phenyl-1-(p-tolyl)prop‑2-yn-1-yl)morpholine] products (indicated as A3a). All the isolated desired products were characterized by taking 1H and 13C NMR. A schematic representation of Ag-NPs@PDVTA-1 catalyzed one pot three component A3 coupling reaction is shown in Scheme 2 . 2.5 Instrumentations Solid catalysts was recovered by centrifugation using R8C Remi bench Centrifuger operating at 4500 rpm. Ultrasound Treatment was applied by using Digital Ultrasound Cleaner Instrument; Model No. LMUC-3 at an applied operating power of 100 W with frequency 40 kHz. The entire FT-IR spectrum was recorded on transmittance mode by using PerkinElmer, Spectrum 100 FT-IR Spectrometer. UV–Vis analysis were executed by using Agilent Cary Series UV–Vis–NIR Spctrophotometer model No. Cary −5000 UV–Vis NIR. All 1H NMR spectra was recorded on Bruker Advance 400 MHz NMR spectrometer as solutions in CDCl3. Chemical shifts are expressed in parts per million (δ) and the signals were reported as s (singlet), d (doublet), t (triplet), m (multiplet), and coupling constants j were given in Hz. 13C NMR spectra were recorded at 100 MHz in CDCl3 solution. Chemical shifts are expressed in parts per million (δ) and are referenced to CDCl3 (δ = 77.16) as an internal standard. Solid-state 13C CP-MAS NMR study was performed using Bruker Advanced-II 600 MHz MAS-NMR spectrometer with a MAS frequency of 8 kHz by using a 4 nm MAS probe. Powder X-ray diffraction studies were carried out with Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer using Ni-filtered Cu Kα (λ = 0.15406 nm) radiation as X-ray source. Diffraction patterns in the wide angle region (6°−90°) were recorded at a rate of (2θ)=0.4° per min.Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) measurement was carried out using PerkinElmer TA-SDT Q-600 thermal analyzer under compressed air flow with heating rate 10 °C/min. N2 adsorption/desorption studies were performed with an i-Sorb-HP1 surface analyzer (Anton Paar Quanta Tec, USA) at 77 K. Prior to the measurement, the sample was degassed in vacuum at 150 °C for 6 h to remove all the guest molecules present within the material. The specific surface area was estimated by using BET model and the PSD was derived by the NLDFT method from adsorption branch of the isotherm with slit pore model as reference. Entire external morphological studies of the POP and catalyst along with all associated analysis and elemental mapping were done by using JEOL JEM 6700 FE-SEM instrument with EDS attachment, operated at 1 – 20 kV. Ultra high resolution transmission electron microscopic (TEM) images of the catalyst, were taken by using a UHR-FEG TEM system (JEOL JEM 2100 F) transmission electron microscope operating at 200 kV electron source. Samples were prepared by dropping a sonicated isopropanol diluted solution of the materials over a carbon coated copper grid followed by drying under high vacuum. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) were recorded on an Omicron nanotech operated at 15 kV and 20 mA with a monochromatic Al Kα X-ray source. The spectrum was calibrated using a C 1s peak at 284.5 eV as the reference. Elemental analysis (C, H, N) was done in a PerkinElmer 2400 Series II CHNS analyzer. Ag content within the prepared catalyst was measured by using PerkinElmer Optima 2100 DV ICP-OES instrument. Resonance Raman analysis was performed on a Tripple Raman System havig Model T-64,000 (Make J-Y Horiba) using 532 nm excitation from a DPSS laser excitation. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 FT-IR analysis To understand the formation of desired bonding and atom connectivity, FT-IR analysis of both PDVTA-1 and Ag-NPs@PDVTA-1 was carried out and the results are shown in Fig. 1 . FT-IR spectrum of the pristine POP (Fig. 1a) shows all characteristics peaks as reported earlier [4]. Aromatic CH stretching vibration bands appeared at 3100–3015 cm−1. Two distinct bands at 2929 cm−1 and 2850 cm−1 arises due to the different CH vibrations, corresponding to non-identical CH bonds in the poly DVB and TAA matrixes along with methylene CH stretching vibration associated with a strong peak at 1446 cm−1. The peak at 1605 cm−1 and 1516 cm−1 appears due to the aromatic C = C stretching vibration of the benzene ring. The peak at 1375 cm−1 could be attributed to the CN stretching. The other peak observed in the range of 825, 795 and 712 cm−1 may be attributed to the different out of plane CH bending/wagging [4,35,43]. On the other hand, the Ag-NPs@PDVTA-1(Fig. 1b) contains all similar characteristics peaks associated as that of the mother POP along with a peakshifting occurs at the CN stretching region; 1369, 1316 and 1273 cm−1 because of the coordination between the heavy-metal (Ag) atom and electron-rich nitrogen. This causes an alteration in the bond length, ultimately leading to a variation in their stretching frequency [35]. Thus, the FTIR spectrum supports the formation of silver nanoparticles in the PDVTA-1 matrix around N center proximity. Further, to confirm any form of structural changes of Ag-NPs@PDVTA-1 catalyst during catalysis we have collected the catalyst at the half way stage of the reaction and at the end of the reaction. Both of them provides unchanged FT-IR spectral pattern as that of the fresh catalyst confirming no structural deformation of the material (Fig. 1c). Again to confirm structural sustainability we have compared the FT-IR spectra of the recovered Ag-NPs@PDVTA-1 catalyst after 6th reaction cycle (Fig. 1d). Unchanged FT-IR spectral pattern as that of the fresh catalyst indicates that our supported Ag-catalyst is highly stable for carrying out repeativite reactions. 3.2 PXRD analysis Powder X-ray diffraction spectra of both the PDVTA-1 and Ag-NPs@PDVTA-1 are shown in Fig. 2 . The pristine PDVTA-1-POP (Fig. 2a) shows a broad and intense hump at 2θ values 20° indicates formation of amorphous material due to the random polymerization of monomers due to their probable rapid cross linking. On the other hand, Ag-NPs@PDVTA-1 (Fig. 2b) displays similar broadening of intense hump attributes amorphous nature; along with series of additional sharp peaks at 2θ = 38.5°, 44.5°, 65° and 78°. These could be attributed to the (111), (200), (220) and (311) planes, respectively of a face-centered cubic nanostructure of Ag0 NPs stuck at the surface of the PDVTA-1-POP vide JCPDS card no. 4–0783. Further calculation of the experimental 2θ values confirms the existence of Ag0 NPs in Ag-NPs@PDVTA-1 material having unit cell value of a = 4.038 Å [44]. Noticeable little shifts of hump of the Ag-NPS@PDVTA-1 compared to that of PDVTA-1, appeared at 2θ values >20° suggests successful loading of Ag0 NPs at the surface of the POP because of grafting of Ag-NPs inside/around pore channels of the of the PDVTA-1 POP showed an enhancement in the contrast of the electron density, which in turn reflected as an increase in intensity of the powder X-ray diffraction pattern [45,46]. So, it is evidenced Ag0 NPs has successfully been grafted through the reaction between PDVTA-1 POP and AgNO3 under open air condition. Similarly, here also to confirm any form of structural changes of Ag-NPs@PDVTA-1 catalyst along with the oxidation state of the Ag0 NPs during catalysis we have collected the catalyst at the half way stage of the reaction and at the end of the reaction, both of them provides unchanged PXRD spectral pattern as that of the fresh catalyst confirming unchanged oxidation state of the Ag NPs with no structural deformation of the material (Fig. 2c). Further, to understand the stability of the reused catalyst, we have compared the PXRD spectra of the recovered Ag-NPs@PDVTA-1 catalyst after 6th cycle of catalysis; (Fig. 2d) unchanged spectral pattern as that of the fresh catalyst indicates our material is very stable upto 6th reaction cycle without having any structural deformation. 3.3 Solid state CP-MAS NMR analysis To establish whether the prepared PDVTA-1-POP is at par with the proposed structure we have carried out the 13C solid state CP MAS NMR studies and the corresponding spectrum is shown in Fig. 3 . In the above shown polymeric framework (Scheme 1) we can categories the entire carbon atoms with all possible different electronic environments into 3 segments; (a) 30 numbers of aromatic carbon atoms, (b) 15 numbers of aliphatic saturated carbon atoms from benzene ring to N atoms and (c) 8 numbers of aliphatic saturated carbon atoms from one benzene ring to another benzene ring. In addition little probable terminal aliphatic sp2 carbons might be there due to the presence of little un-reacted DVB monomers. The possible ideal theoretical chemical shifts were shown in the theoretical prediction model in Fig. 3a. The intense peaks spread over the range from 150 to 120 ppm may be attributed to the segment (a) aromatic carbons. The broad intense little bifurcated peak spread over the range from 55 ppm to 37 ppm and a little intense peak at around 20 ppm is due to the segment (b) and (c) aliphatic carbons along with a small tell hump even in lower ppm region. The little peak appeared at around 115 ppm is due to the presence of little terminal sp2 carbons. Hence it can be concluded our prepared PDVTA-1-POP really fits well with the proposed structure along with all other identities [4]. 3.4 N2 adsorption-desorption study To understand the porosity and surface properties of both PDVTA-1 and Ag-NPs@PDVTA-1 materials N2 adsorption-desorption analysis has been carried out and the corresponding isotherms are shown in Fig. 4 a and 4b respectively. Random radical polymerization of olefin moieties with multiple alkyl branches in the presence of AIBN radical initiator could leads to the formation of intrinsic porosity and void spaces due to rapid cross-linking [47]. BET isotherms of PDVTA-1 POP can be classified as type IV isotherm; corresponding to large micropores, with a significant H2 type hysteresis loop in the high pressure region (0.5–0.8 relative N2 pressure) suggesting the presence of mesoporosity [48,49]. BET surface area and pore volume of PDVTA-1 is found to be 740 m2g−1 and 0.551 cm3g−1, respectively. Nonlocal density function theory (NLDFT) was employed to estimate the pore size distribution (PSD). PSD of PDVTA-1 (Fig. 4a inset) showed two major peaks with dimensions of 1.68 and 3.90 nm, respectively. De Boer statistical thickness (t-plot) analysis provides the micropore vs mesopore contributions towards SSA and is found to be 626 m2g−1 and 114 m2g−1, respectively, reveals dominating microporous nature of the pristine POP. On the other hand Ag-NPs@PDVTA-1 material shows similar trend in the isotherm even after impregnation of Ag-NPs with an additional little capillary rise in adsorption at 0.4 relative pressure region. This may be attributed to either of bottle neck mesopore opening due to NPs loading or enhancement of mesoporosity due to the loading of Ag-NPs in the POP may create additional inter particle voids that follows later on steady uptake [49]. Calculated BET SSA and pore volume is found to be 690 m2g−1 and 0.541 cm3g−1, respectively. NLDFT PSD results unchanged microporous pickpore width along with a little reduced mesopore width 3.79 nm. Only change in mesoporous distribution indicates formation of Ag-NPs having sizes above the micropore dimensions. Further lowering of all these parameters (surface area, pore size and pore volume) in the Ag-NPs@PDVTA-1 dictates, there is a successful decoration of Ag NPs at the surface of the PDVTA-1-POP material, results formation of Ag-NPs@PDVTA-1 catalyst. 3.5 Thermogravimetric analysis Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of both the PDVTA-1 and Ag-NPs@PDVTA-1 has been carried out for a wide temperature range from 35 to 800 °C with a temperature ramp of 10 °C min−1 under N2 flow (Figs. S1 and S2). The TGA curve obtained for PDVTA-1-POP (Fig. S1) reveals it is thermally stable up to 360 °C without any weight loss throughout the range. On the other hand, the TGA plot of Ag-NPs@PDVTA-1 (Fig. S2) follows the same trend as that of the pristine PDVTA-1, suggesting the heavy metal NPs loaded POP framework is also stable upto 360 °C. After that a significant continuous decrease in the weight is observed beyond 360 °C for both of them, which could be attributed to the gradual and continuous degradation of the organic framework. This reveals, our polymeric material is highly stable up to a large temperature span (upto 360 °C), within which the liquid phase and any kind of neat condition catalytic reactions are usually carried out. It is also evident that if any strong endothermic neat condition catalysis may be carried out at an elevated temperature our supported Ag NPs must perform well because of its thermally robust nature. 3.6 UV–Vis and elemental analysis The UV–Vis spectra of PDVTA-1 and Ag-NPs@PDVTA-1 are shown in Fig. 5 a and 5b, respectively. PDVTA-1 shows strong peaks at 221, 257, 289, 322 nm, which could be attributed to the different aliphatic and aromatic chromophoric moieties present in their structure as reported earlier [4]. UV–Vis spectrum of the catalyst Ag-NPs@PDVTA-1 (Fig. 5b) shows an additional hump at around 400 nm, which could be attributed to the Ag0 plasmon resonance band [42]. Elemental analysis results the C, H and N content of Ag-NPs@PDVTA-1 as: C = 89.38%, H = 7.59% and N = 1.99%, which agrees well with the theoretical calculation of C, H, N of 4:1 for divinyl benzene and triallylamine as that have been used in this work to prepare PDVTA-1-POP. As per Scheme-1 structure, theoretical calculated value of C, H, N content of PDVTA-1 are C = 89.56%, H = 8.39%, and N = 2.04% [4]. When we have used 10, 15 and 20 wt% of AgNO3 with respect to the weight of PDVTA-1, corresponding estimated Ag loading in the final catalysts were found to be 3.3, 4.45 and 5.04% respectively (ICP-OES analysis). Among them 3.3% Ag loaded sample (Ag-NPs@PDVTA-1) was used for the entire catalysis. 3.7 Morphological analysis 3.7.1 FE-SEM analysis FE-SEM images of the Ag-NPs@PDVTA-1 at different magnifications are shown in Fig. 6 a, b. These figures represent well defined spherical self-assembled nanoparticles. It is also visible that several tiny spherical nanospheres of dimensions ca (20–25) nm are adhere with each other at the surfaces to form aggregated nanoparticles [50]. Formations of different aggregates having sizes up to 400 nm are due to the random polymerization during the synthesis of PDVTA-1 POP. From this FE SEM image the interparticle void between these tiny/aggregated nanoparticles is quite clearly visible, which can be attributed to the inherent mesoporocity with an average pore size 4.0 nm and this result agrees well with the NLDFT PSD results. Further to confirm the distribution of Ag NPs over this POP matrix elemental mapping was done for N and Ag atoms (Fig. 6c, d), which shows uniform distribution of the Ag NPs throughout the POP matrix and this confirms the successful loading of Ag-NPs. 3.7.2 UHR-TEM analysis Further, we have analyzed the nanostructure of this co-polymer through ultra high resolution TEM and corresponding images are shown in Fig. 7 . It is evident from these images that denser spherical Ag NPs are distributed in the comparatively lighter and brighter organic POP matrix as seen as the dark spots throughout the specimen grid in Ag-NPs@PDVTA-1 (Fig. 7a, b, c). Hence, this result proves successful grafting of Ag NPs in the polymeric matrix. It is further evident the particle sizes of these Ag NPs over the POP support is estimated to be in the ranges 7.5–12.6 nm. Ag0 naonparticles size histogram is shown in the Fig. S3 (supplementary information) indicates 10 nm is average /mean particle size. The FFT (Fast Fourier Transformation) pattern given in the inset of Fig. 7c of specified area indicates the corresponding planes as observed in the PXRD pattern vide JCPDS card No. 4–0783 [42]. Selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern also shown in Fig. 7d, provides further proof about the presence of Ag NPs embedded over the POP matrix, where the electron diffraction spots represents Ag NPs as described JCPDS card No. 4–0783. TEM images of recycled catalyst after 6th cycle of catalysis (Fig. S4) clearly indicates the retention of structural morphology of catalyst even after repeated washing and drying throughout all consecutive reaction cycles. 3.8 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) To understand the surface chemistry of all constituent elements, XPS analysis was carried out for the Ag-NPs@PDVTA-1 material. The spectra of C 1s, Ag 3d are shown in Fig. 8 , N 1s and full scale XPS are shown in Figs. S5 and S6. High resolution XPS dedicated for C 1s shows clubbing of three peaks for three different C 1 s at binding energies 283.8, 284.35 and 285.3 eV (Fig. 8a), may be attributed to the 1s C of C = C, CC and CN present in the organic framework of the PDVTA-1 matrix [51]. Whereas narrow range N shows single 1s peak at their respective desired position of 399.5 eV as they are present only one form in the framework (Fig. S5). Ag 3d gives typical doublet resulting from spin-orbital splitting of 3d electrons, corresponding to Ag 3d3/2 and 3d5/2, respectively, at 369.5 and 375.5 eV (Fig. 8b). These values are in good agreement with the reported binding energies of typical Ag0 NPs spectral profile [48,52]. The narrow width of the peaks attributes solitary existence of zero valence silver nanoparticles, which correlates PXRD data. Existence of tertiary N provides fastening interaction with the silver nanoparticles [53]. Hence, XPS analysis suggested that the Ag species in the Ag-NPs@PDVTA-1 are in the zero oxidation state. Full scale XPS for all elements present in the catalyst is shown in the (Fig. S6), suggesting the presence of other major constituent elements C and N within the supported PDVTA-1-POP matrix at their designated binding energy position. 4 Application (Heterogeneous catalysis) We shall discuss our entire catalytic study in two parts. Part A: optimization of one pot three component (A3) coupling reaction conditions with reaction mechanism and versatility and Part B: to ensure its degree of heterogeneity and reusability. 4.1 Part-A: Optimization of A3 coupling reaction conditions 4.1.1 Model test reactions To check the feasibility/ efficiency of this heterogeneous Ag-NPs@PDVTA-1 catalyst, we have performed a test A3 coupling reactions by choosing 4-methylbenzaldehyde (1a), morpholine (2a), and phenylacetylene (3a) as model substrates, and carried out the one-pot three-component reaction using Ag-NPs@PDVTA-1 to get respective propargylamine (A3a) derivatives. In contrast to several reported homo/heterogeneous catalysts for this reaction, heterogeneous Ag° catalysts still have a wide opportunity to explore as and when the catalyst is thermally/chemically robust, reusable and if proceeded without solvent. Initially, 4-methylbenzaldehyde (1 mmol), morpholine (1.2 mmol), phenylacetylene (1.5 mmol), Ag-NPs@PDVTA-1 catalyst (5 mg) and tetrahydrofuran (THF- 5 mL) was taken at its refluxing temperature for 10 h. The Ag-catalyst is highly effective in this reaction and provides the corresponding propargylamine product. On the other hand, when the reaction was carried out in the absence of the catalyst only trace amount of product was noticed. However, when AgNO3 was used as catalyst only 25% isolated yield of propargylamine was obtained (Table 1 , entry 17). 4.1.2 Optimization of reaction conditions After getting positive results, we have explored different solvents to obtain maximum propargylamine yield. Various protic and aprotic solvents were tested for this reaction, such as THF, water, ethanol, toluene, acetonitrile, 1, 2-DCE, and as well as solvent-free neat conditions (Table 1, Entry 3–7). We observed that neat condition reaction provides highest isolated yields (75%) compared to other solvents under comparable reaction conditions. Inspired by this result, the reaction was further optimised using neat conditions by employing different amounts of catalyst (3–20 mg) and at the end, it reveals the desired amount of product was obtained with 5 mg of catalyst; without having significant change in the yield using higher catalyst amount (Table 1, Entry 7–10). Keeping the same neat condition with 5 mg catalyst amount next stage of optimization was done by varying the reaction time from 10 to 15 h (Table 1, Entry 10–12) provides highest yields of 83%, suggesting 12 h is the optimized reaction time. Role of reaction temperature was also evaluated (Table 1, Entry 13–15) for this reaction and at 100 °C it led to the maximum yield in contrast above/below the temperature is less productive for this processes. 4.1.3 Substrate scope After optimizing the reaction condition, the versatility and efficiency of the catalysis were checked by employing various types of aromatic aldehydes, secondary amines, and terminal alkynes. The treatment of 4-Methylbenzaldehyde (1a) with morpholine (2a) and phenylacetylene (3a) successfully lead to the formation of the desired propargylamine A3a in 83% yield. After getting this excellent outcome, we carried out series of reactions with some para-substituted (-Br, -Cl, -F) benzaldehyde, and the corresponding products A3b, A3c and A3d; resulted with very good yields (80–83%). Naphthaldehyde also participates in this reaction with the formation of the corresponding propargylamine A3e with a good amount of yield (79%). Moreover, heterocyclic aromatic aldehyde such as thiophene-2-carbaldehyde also underwent the reaction to provide the corresponding coupling product A3f with a yield of 74%. After that, we used salicylaldehyde and 5-chlorosalicylaldehyde as an aldehyde for the preparation of the corresponding propargylamine A3g and A3h with good yields (78–81%). It is worthy to mention that different types of para-substituted (-CH3, OCH3, t-Bu, -F) phenylacetylene were also effective for this reaction to achieve the expected products A3i, A3j, A3k, A3l, and A3m, where three different types of aldehyde derivatives gave good yields. Further, we examined the reaction by taking another cyclic secondary amine, piperidine for the preparation of the corresponding propargylamine A3n, which also affords good yield (78%). Table 2 showed formation of various propargyleamines as discussed above with very good to excellent yields. Formation of all respective propargylamines are characterised by 1H and 13C NMR spectra and they are shown in Figs. S7 – S20 along with their respective spectral details in Table S1. It is pertinent to mention that the catalytic efficiency of the heterogeneous catalyst is expressed in terms of turn over numbers (TONs). TON is defined as the number of moles of substrate converted per mole of the active site of the catalyst. Hence to calculate TON for our catalyst from the wt% of Ag, mol% of Ag was calculated and ultimately TON was calculated and is found to be in the range from 553 to 493. The details indicative calculation is shown in the Section S1. Table 3 shows comparison of this Ag-NPs@PDVTA-1 catalyst with other reported work. 4.1.4 Proposed reaction mechanism A probable mechanistic pathway has been demonstrated based on the literature data in Fig. 9 [26–28,54–56]. At first, there was a formation of iminium ions (A) from the initial reaction between an aromatic aldehyde and secondary amine. Then, Ag NPs activate the CH bond of the terminal alkyne and forms terminal alyne cabon-metal bond. After that, the iminium ions reacted with the silver-acetylide intermediate (B) and forms the desired propargylamine product (C). Therefore, to establish the catalytic evidence in support of the proposed mechanism a comparative Raman analysis was carried out for our catalyst before and at the middle of the reaction as shown in Fig. 10 a and b, respectively. The formation of this terminal alkyne C-Ag bond was confirmed from its characteristics Raman shift at about 2100 cm−1 [55] for our catalyst at the middle of the reaction; in contrast that band is totally absent in the pure form of the pristine catalyst. So it is evidenced that our Ag-catalyst actively takes part into the one pot tree component coupling reaction and it follows the proposed reaction mechanism. 4.2 Part-B: Ensuring of degree of heterogeneity and reusability 4.2.1 Heterogeneity test A controlled leaching experiment was carried out in this A3 coupling reaction ( Table 2, Entry 1) over Ag-NPs@PDVTA-1 catalyst so as to understand whether there is any trace amount of Ag being leached out from the catalyst or not. Among the various proofs of heterogeneity, a simple and convenient process filtration was carried out by separating the catalyst at the half way stage of the reaction. Similarly here the catalyst is separated after 6 h advancement of the reaction by simple filtration from the reaction mixture and the filtrate i.e., the reaction mixture was allowed to react up to 12 h i.e., till its completion time. No further reaction advancement was noticed, which revealed the catalyst is perfectly heterogeneous by performance. Moreover, there was no evidence of decomposition of the solid catalyst during the entire catalytic reaction. To ensure its optimum heterogeneity the supernatant of the reaction mixture as collected by simple filtration, was examined through ICP-OES, results complete absence of Ag (<0.1 ppm) in the liquid phase. Hence,we can conclude that no leaching of Ag species from the catalyst surface occurred to the reaction medium during the entire course of the reaction. 4.2.2 Recyclability test For any heterogeneous catalyst recyclability is the most important aspect, where its potentiality for easy separation from the reaction mixture, recoverability and reusability are accounted. The reusability of the Ag-NPs@PDVTA-1 catalyst was studied in this A3 coupling reaction under the optimized reaction conditions (Table 2, entry 1). After first cycle of the reaction, the catalyst was collected by simple filtration, washed with ethanol and then with water and was oven dried at 100 °C or by simple air dried for 2 days. Then the catalyst was reused for the next cycle of heterogeneous catalysis. Up to six consecutive cycles the performance of the recycled catalyst for the targeted reaction was tested by keeping other conditions same and the corresponding isolated product yields are shown in Fig. 11 . This plot indicates that the catalytic activity of the recovered catalyst decreased from 83% to 74% only for A3a after six consecutive reaction cycles. This result suggested considerably good recycling efficiency of our supported Ag-nanocatalyst. 5 Conclusion Our experimental results suggests that Ag nanoparticles can be grafted on the surface of a pure organic porous polymer material bearing N-sites and having high specific surface area. Resulting supported Ag-nanomaterial can be utilized as a heterogeneous catalyst for one pot three component A3 coupling reaction to produce different type of propargylamine derivatives from the respective substrates. The catalyst provides several advantages in this A3 coupling reaction; such as convenient and mild reaction conditions, ligand-free protocol, use of low Ag content (3.3% by ICP-OES), reaction under neat condition (without any solvent), high yields (upto 83%) of products with high TONs ranging (553–493), good recyclability along with negligible loss of silver while recycling. Thus, such a green process of A3 coupling reaction catalyzed by this efficient and highly recyclable Ag NPs grafted porous organic polymer reported herein, will gain further attention in the synthesis of value added organic compounds via A3 coupling reaction in future. coredata.dc:description: Designing of low cost catalytic system for new CC/CN/CO bond formation reactions is very challenging in synthetic organic chemistry. Herein, we report a new Ag NPs immobilized porous organic polymer (POP) material Ag-NPs@PDVTA-1 by grafting of Ag nanoparticles at the surface of a POP material PDVTA-1. PDVTA-1 has been synthesized via radical co-polymerization of divinylbenzene and triallylamine under solvothermal reaction conditions. PDVTA-1 as well as the Ag-loaded catalyst Ag-NPs@PDVTA-1 are fully characterized to understand their physico-chemical properties. Ag-NPs@PDVTA-1 is used as heterogeneous nanocatalyst for the one pot three component A3 coupling reaction of aldehyde, secondary amine and terminal alkyne for the synthesis of a wide range of propargylamine derivatives under mild and eco-friendly reaction conditions. The desired products were obtained in high yields over this environmentally safe catalyst under optimized reaction conditions. Remarkably high specific surface area of Ag-NPs@PDVTA-1 (694 m2g−1) and its highly accessible catalytically active Ag-sites in the nano-architecture potentially makes it an efficient catalyst as reflected from the respective turn over numbers. The catalyst was collected and reused for several reaction cycles without any noticeable decline in its catalytic activity, suggesting its high merit in heterogeneous catalysis for the synthesis of value added CC/CN coupling products via one pot coupling reaction.
coredata.dc:title: Ag nanoparticles grafted porous organic polymer as an efficient heterogeneous catalyst for solvent-free A3 coupling reactions

dcterms:subject.$: One pot three component A3 coupling
